xxl.core.xxlinq.columns
Class Column

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.functions.AbstractFunction<Tuple,java.lang.Object>
      xxl.core.xxlinq.columns.Column
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable, Function<Tuple,java.lang.Object>, CorrTuplesReceiver
Direct Known Subclasses:
IndexedColumn, ReflectionColumn
public class Column
extends AbstractFunction<Tuple,java.lang.Object>
implements CorrTuplesReceiver

This class represents a single value/object, among other things to be used in predicates and to select and create new Columns in select.
The object is retrieved by calling invoke(Tuple) or invoke(Tuple, Tuple) and most commonly a Column will return the Object contained in one specific column of the tuple (thus the name).
But this class (or subclasses of this class) is also used for static values like ColumnUtils.val(Object), calculated values like ADD(Column) that create a new Column from to given Columns, values obtained via reflection from a method-call on an Object from a column of the tuple (see ReflectionColumn) and to access values of "correlated tuples" in subqueries like EXISTS etc.

See Also:
Serialized Form

public static java.util.Comparator<java.lang.Object> equalsPseudoComp
Pseudo-Comparator that compares two Objects for equality and returns 0 if they're equal and 1 if they aren't. To be used with EQ and NEQ when both Objects are of the same type.

Method Detail

invoke

public java.lang.Object invoke(Tuple tuple)
Returns an the Object represented by this Column. That may be the value of one column of the given tuple, a correlated tuple, a value calculated from contained columns or just a fixed value.

Specified by:
invoke in interface Function<Tuple,java.lang.Object>
Overrides:
invoke in class AbstractFunction<Tuple,java.lang.Object>
Parameters:
tuple - the argument to the function.
Returns:
the function value is returned.

invoke

public java.lang.Object invoke(Tuple left,
                               Tuple right)
Returns an the Object represented by this Column. That may be the value of one column of the given tuples, a value calculated from contained columns or just a fixed value.

Specified by:

setMetaData

public void setMetaData(AdvResultSetMetaData metadata,
                        java.lang.String newAlias)
Set the AdvResultSetMetaData of the cursor this column (probably) belongs to and the new alias of the resulting cursor.
It also passes on the MetaData to it's "contained" Colums (e.g. if this Column represents a concatenation of two other Columns it's passed on to them). If you're using this in a join Predicate you will have to set the AdvResultSetMetaData of both joined Cursors - just invoke this Method with each of them, the metadata with the first match for the internal name will be used.

Parameters:
metadata - AdvResultSetMetaData of the cursor, you're calling where/select/group_by on with this column
newAlias - the new alias of the resulting cursor after where/select/group_by (needed especially if this Column contains a given value from val(obj, name))

setMetaDatas

public void setMetaDatas(AdvResultSetMetaData leftMetaData,
                         AdvResultSetMetaData rightMetaData)
When used in a JOIN-Predicate, set the AdvResultSetMetaDatas of the the left and right Cursors that are joined. So the Column can decide whether to use the left or the right tuple in invoke(left, right).
The metadatas will be also be passed on to contained Columns.

Parameters:
leftMetaData - AdvResultSetMetaData of the left cursor being joined
rightMetaData - AdvResultSetMetaData of the right cursor being joined

addContainedColumns

public void addContainedColumns(Column... cols)
Add columns "contained" in this one so metadata and correlated tuples can be set for them.
You have contained columns with CONCAT(), ADD() etc.
Example:
col("al1.nameX").CONCAT(col("al2.nameY"), "foo") creates a new Column named foo from the Columns "al1.nameX" and "al2.nameY" that should be present in your cursor or the correlated tuples.
Metadata will be set for this Column (in select/where/...), but not for "al1.nameX" and "al2.nameY" which actually need the metadata to map to the right column.. So "foo" gets a list of those Columns and when setMetaData() or setCorrelatedTuples() is called upon "foo", it will call it on "al1.nameX" and "al2.nameY".

Parameters:
cols - Columns to be contained in this Column

setCorrelatedTuples

public void setCorrelatedTuples(java.util.List<MapEntry<AdvResultSetMetaData,Tuple>> corrTuples)
Pass a list of tuples along with their metadata from "outer" cursors in case this is a (correlated) subquery. The list has to be sorted from inside to outside (in case of nested subqueries). With the name given to this column the object will be fetched from the the first tuple with a column with according alias and name and this object will be bound to this column.
This is meant to be used with EXISTS, ALL and ANY clauses.

Specified by:
setCorrelatedTuples in interface CorrTuplesReceiver
Parameters:
corrTuples - a List of tuples with their related metadata from "outer" cursors for correlated subqueries
See Also:
AdvTupleCursor#getCorrTuples()

getColumnIndex

public int getColumnIndex()
Returns:
the index of the column in a tuple this Column represents

getColumnMetaData

public ColumnMetaData getColumnMetaData()
Returns:
the ColumnMetaData for this Column, if it has a name.
Throws:
a - RuntimeException if this Column has no name (e.g. an unnamed val())

                       java.util.Comparator cmp)

cmp - your custom comparator (null for default)

EQ

public AdvPredicate EQ(Column.SubQueryType type,
                       AdvTupleCursor subquery)
Returns an AdvPredicate performing a comparison for EQuality with a (possibly correlated) ANY/ALL-subquery.
Note: The subquery must return a cursor with only a single column!
Example: 
 SELECT * FROM c1 
        WHERE c1.a1 = ANY (SELECT b1 FROM c2)
 will be something like:
c1.where( col("c1.a1").EQ( SubQueryType.ANY, c2.select(col("c2.b1")) ) )

Parameters:
type - the Column.SubQueryType of the subquery (SubQueryType.ANY or SubQueryType.ALL)
subquery - the subquery itself (an AdvTupleCursor), possibly correlated
Returns:
an appropriate AdvPredicate to be used in where()

EQ

public AdvPredicate EQ(Column.SubQueryType type,
                       AdvTupleCursor subquery,
                       java.util.Comparator cmp)
Returns an AdvPredicate performing a comparison for EQuality with a custom comparator with a (possibly correlated) ANY/ALL-subquery.
Note: The subquery must return a cursor with only a single column!

Parameters:
type - the Column.SubQueryType of the subquery (SubQueryType.ANY or SubQueryType.ALL)
subquery - the subquery itself (an AdvTupleCursor), possibly correlated
cmp - a Comparator to be used or null to use a standard comparator
Returns:
an appropriate AdvPredicate to be used in where()
See Also:
EQ(type, subquery) for a small example how ANY/ALL-subqueries are used

LIKE

public AdvPredicate LIKE(java.lang.String regex)
Returns an AdvPredicate checking if this Columns value as a String (using Object.toString()) matches with the given regular expression.
The regular expression uses the java.util.regex classes, so see Pattern for details on how the regex has to look like.

Parameters:
regex - the regular expression used for comparison
Returns:
an AdvPredicate checking if this Columns value as a String matches the given regex

CONCAT

public Column CONCAT(Column col)
Parameters:
col - the Column this Column will be concatenated with
Returns:
a Column containing a String that is a concatenaton of the strings (Object.toString) from this Column and col

                     java.lang.String name)
Parameters:
col - the Column this Column will be concatenated with
name - the created Columns name
Returns:
a Column with given name containing a String that is a concatenaton of the strings (Object.toString) from this Column and col

ADD

public Column ADD(Column col)
Performs summation of this Column's value with col's value.
Both need to contain Numbers, i.e. evaluate to values of a class derived from Number!

Parameters:
col -
Returns:
a Column containing the result of the calculation as a Double

ADD

public Column ADD(Column col,
                  java.lang.String name)
Performs summation ("plus") of this Column's value with col's value.
Both need to contain Numbers, i.e. evaluate to values of a class derived from Number!

Parameters:
col -
name - name of the new Column (if it's to be an actual column in a tuple)
Returns:
a Column containing the result of the calculation as a Double

MUL

public Column MUL(Column col)
Performs multiplication of this Column's value with col's value.
Both need to contain Numbers, i.e. evaluate to values of a class derived from Number!

Parameters:
col -
Returns:
a Column containing the result of the calculation as a Double

POW

public Column POW(Column col)
Performs an exponentiation with this Column's value being the base and col's value being the exponent.
Both need to contain Numbers, i.e. evaluate to values of a class derived from Number!

any_all_subquery

protected AdvPredicate any_all_subquery(Column.SubQueryType type,
                                        AdvTupleCursor subquery,
                                        Predicate<java.lang.Object> pred)
Creates an ALL/ANY subquery on the given cursor with the given Predicate.
Example:
In AdvPredicate EQ(type, subquery) you just create a Predicate that compares two Objects(!) for equality and pass it on to this method: 
 public AdvPredicate simple_EQ(final SubQueryType type, final AdvTupleCursor subquery){
        Predicate
